Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the father needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Story: I was just finishing up my shift at the supermarket, scrubbing the floors and making sure every surface gleamed, when I heard my son’s name over the intercom. My heart skipped. I rushed to the front, still in my cleaner’s uniform, gloves and mask on, the scent of disinfectant clinging to me. There he was, eyes wide, a half-opened bag of chips in his hand. The store manager looked at me expectantly, waiting for me to handle it as a parent. I knew what was expected: I had to teach my son right from wrong, show him that stealing is unacceptable, and discipline him firmly but fairly. But I was also still on the clock, and the store had strict hygiene rules—no removing gloves or mask, no touching anyone without sanitizing. My son reached for me, tears in his eyes, wanting comfort. I hesitated, torn between the urge to hold him and the rules drilled into me as a cleaner. The manager’s gaze, my son’s trembling hands, the latex gloves between us—I stood there, caught between being the father he needed and the employee I was supposed to be.
